Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned all about ancient Mesoamerica.
Learned about the crazy world of ancient Mesoamerica! Definitely not just the Aztecs.
I learned a lot about a culture/history that I knew nothing about.
I learned the history and traditions of the Aztecs
Researching and presenting the information in a concise way.
Learned about the cultural history of the Aztec Empire as well as surrounding Mesoamerican cultures. Learned the techniques utilized to learn about these cultures.
I learned more about Aztec history and culture. I thought I had an understanding of the people, but lectures about gods, rituals, and daily life showed me there is still much to learn.

It was a bit disorganized - maybe if the weeks had clearer themes I would've learned better and been more engaged. 
Covered a lot of ground and was truly fascinating. Chinchilla is clearly a specialist and is good at explaining concepts.
Some very very interesting material if you enjoy history and mythology, but the presentation of the material was sometimes a little dry.

I think this course would've been better if taught as a seminar than a lecture, just because a lot of the lectures involved reading primary source documents in class, which would've been better as assigned readings to be discussed in class.
I think the course material was very interesting, but I don't think it was presented as well as it could have been.
Strength was that the course was very interactive due to the weekly field trips that we had. I really appreciated using the resources that Yale has to offer.

I found the material interesting, but lectures were hard to follow. The overarching themes were outlined in the readings, but at the end of lecture I never had a sense of the bigger picture or how any one topic fit in with everything else. I did appreciate the trips we took to museums and libraries around campus.

Strengths: The class is pretty small so I felt comfortable asking questions and delving deeper into a topic. Although it was a pretty small class, I wish there were more interactive activities that took place in the classroom, although class field trips were very interesting!
Weaknesses: Reading workloads were somewhat hard to manage, weekly quizzes could have prepared us for discussion and been study guides for exams.
Strength: lots of engaging extra-classroom activities.
If you're legitimately interested in the topic then yes!! But, if you're just taking it for distribution requirements, it's a lot of work.
If you are very interested in Mesoamerica/Aztecs, then yes
Yes, I would very much recommend this course to another student, especially anthropology and history students.
If you are very much interested in learning about Mesoamerican societies I would recommend it, but I would not recommend it to those with a light interest.

Yes! Oswaldo and Nick are great. It is a really niche class and it uses yale's resources to the best of its ability. There was even a field trip to the MET in which we got to present about objects at the museum.
Absolutely. Oswaldo is a terrific professor and its a very interesting topic, even if youre not interested in archaeology. The class also takes engaging field trips
Yes! This is a class provides a space to learn about a people that do not usually get classes taught about them in places like Yale. It is a good immersion into early Mexican culture.
Yes.
